p: Strong winds were mentioned by several of the interview subjects in the coroner’s report [ 9]. It is evident from photos from the scene of the fire, and reports of fire victims covered by a foot of ice, that it was very cold during the fire. According to Roslin [ 50] “It was one of the coldest days of an unusually nasty winter, even for L’Isle Verte. A bracing northern wind blew all day out of the snowy Charlevoix Mountains. It tore across the frozen mouth of the St. Lawrence River, 25 km wide at this point, and blasted the village of 1400 nestled on the river’s south shore, six hours northeast of Montreal.”
